utterances: Other companies also make this kind of four-seater commuter car.
The Nissan leaf was one of the first.

Dan Sperling, co-director of the National Center for Sustainable Transportation at the University of California, Davis, says there are a number of things you should consider before you buy an electric car.
First, do you just need a car for commuting or other relatively short trips, and what fuel produces the electricity you will use to charge it?
If you buy an electric car in an area where the electricity is made mostly from coal, your car will be the same or possibly even a little worse than a gasoline car.
Ouch.
To find out the source of your electrical energy, search EPA power profiler, and enter your ZIP code.
If you'd like an electric car for commuting but need a car with a longer range for weekend trips, you could consider a plug-in hybrid like the Chevy Volt or the Toyota Prius Plug-in hybrid.
Sperling says they typically have a 25- to 50-mile all-electric range, enough for most people's commute.
Of course, the cost of a new electric or a hybrid is also a big consideration.
Sperling says these days, many are quite affordable partly because automakers are selling them below cost to try to build a market.
So you can actually get an electric car now for a very low price.
Some are available for less than $20,000 after subtracting a $7,500 tax credit from the federal government, and many states provide tax incentives, too.
There is another thing to consider in making a decision, and that's the amount of carbon emitted in manufacturing a new car.
Ten to 15 percent of the total greenhouse gas emissions from that car over the life of the car would be associated with the manufacturing.
So, Sperling says, you won't get any overall reduction in your carbon footprint until you've driven your new, more-efficient car 10,000 to 20,000 miles.
Another big consideration is how much you drive.
Sperling says if you have an older car and you're only driving a few thousand miles a year, it's probably not worth it to upgrade to a cleaner car.

If, however, it's a car that is being used quite a bit - say, 10,00 miles a year or more - there's definitely a high payoff because now there are cars that get 50 miles per gallon compared to your 25.
Of course, the best thing to do for the environment, says Sperling, is walk or bike or use mass transportation.
John Ydstie, NPR News, Washington.
And now a story of activism and espionage.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
We learned last week that PETA - People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals - discovered a mole in their midst.
They believe a volunteer who called himself Tom Jones is actually a SeaWorld employee.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Asabiel knows that the life of a cab driver is risky.
Few have health insurance and many are deeply in debt.
Well, it does put them on equal footing in that neither one is subject to a consent decree.

But the difference is that the RNC has a record of having engaged in activities which have been - appear to be aimed at making it harder for minority voters likely to vote for Democrats to be able to vote.
And that same danger has not at least in recent years been coming from the Democratic Party.
So they might be equal in terms of their legal status, but the dangers are somewhat different for voters.
Rick Hasen is an elections law expert at the University of California, Irvine, speaking with us on Skype.
Thanks very much.
Thank you.
To Iraq now, where a US military helicopter went down today north of Baghdad.
Both crew members were killed.
today, Iraq's electoral commission says it will throw out more than 200 ballot boxes from last month's vote.
The commission is investigating thousands of allegations of fraud in the parliamentary elections.
Earlier from Baghdad, I spoke with Alissa Rubin.
She's a reporter for the Los Angeles Times.
Alissa, welcome back to DAY TO DAY.
There's been a recent increase in these helicopters coming down in Iraq, US military helicopters.
What more can you tell us about today's incident?
Well, I think we don't know a lot about the incident other than what we learned earlier in the day from eyewitnesses.
It happened in a rural area, an area where a helicopter has been shot down in the past; that was quite a while ago now.
It's an area of sort of farming and orchards.
It's north of Baghdad, and it's never been an area that had looked very kindly on the US military's presence and it's always been a very difficult area for US soldiers.

There have been a number of incidents over the full period of the occupation, and now with the soldiers still there, even in that time both in terms of some IED incidents, but also in terms of other effects to ambush soldiers and then the shoot-downs of helicopters.
Of these two incidents last week, has the military there confirmed that one of them was a shoot-down of a helicopter?
I don't know if there has been a formal acknowledgement of that, but that is the understanding that's been made to us, that at least one of them was a shoot-down and possibly both.
Alissa, let me turn to the electoral commission, which is investigating allegations of fraud in the parliamentary elections from last month.
How about these more than 200 ballot boxes that the commission says should be thrown out?
Is that going to matter in the vote count?

Well, I think if you put it in perspective, this is a tiny percentage of--you know, I don't even know if it's 1 percent of the total ballot boxes that were out there, and there are still investigations going on.
Of course, you don't want to have had any fraud, but in terms of a substantial altering of the outcome of the election, that seems very, very unlikely.
There is a real question, and still is, as to the count.

We don't have a final count, and that will be important in terms of whether there's actual majority of seats for the Shia list and--or whether how extensively they need to form coalitions, how many people they need to form the two-thirds majority they would need to get some of the key approval through.
But I don't really think that the fraud is at holds.
There's still a complaint and sort of an appeals process that it will have much impact on the outcome.
Alissa Rubin, a reporter for the Los Angeles Times, joining us from Baghdad.
Alissa, thank you again.
Thank you.
